name: General Data Protection Regulation
summary: The GDPR is a regulation in EU law on data protection and privacy in the European Union and the European Economic Area. It also addresses the transfer of personal data outside the EU and EEA areas. The GDPR's primary aim is to give individuals control over their personal data and to simplify the regulatory environment for international business by unifying the regulation within the EU.

articles.title: Principles relating to processing of personal data
articles.summary: Personal data must be processed lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner. Data must be collected for specified, explicit and legitimate purposes and not further processed in a manner that is incompatible with those purposes.
articles.notes: This is a fundamental principle that applies to all processing activities.

articles.title: Lawfulness of processing
articles.summary: Processing is lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: consent, contract, legal obligation, vital interests, public task, or legitimate interests.
articles.notes: Ensure you have a valid legal basis before processing any personal data.

articles.title: Data protection by design and by default
articles.summary: The controller must implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure data protection principles are effectively implemented and to protect the rights of data subjects.
articles.notes: Privacy must be built into systems from the ground up, not added as an afterthought.

articles.title: Security of processing
articles.summary: The controller and processor must implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk, including pseudonymisation, encryption, and regular security assessments.
articles.notes: Security measures must be proportional to the risk level of the data processing.

articles.title: Notification of a personal data breach to the supervisory authority
articles.summary: In the case of a personal data breach, the controller must notify the supervisory authority within 72 hours of becoming aware of it, unless the breach is unlikely to result in a risk to individuals' rights.
articles.notes: Have an incident response plan ready. Time is critical for breach notifications.

developer_guidance: Encrypt sensitive data at rest and in transit using strong encryption algorithms (AES-256, TLS 1.3+)
Implement role-based access control (RBAC) to ensure only authorized users can access personal data
Minimize personal data storage - only collect and store what is necessary for the stated purpose
Implement data retention policies and automatic deletion of data after retention periods expire
Use pseudonymisation techniques to reduce identifiability of personal data
Log all access to personal data with timestamps, user IDs, and actions performed
Implement consent management systems that allow users to withdraw consent easily
Ensure data portability - provide mechanisms for users to export their data in machine-readable formats
Conduct regular security assessments and penetration testing
Implement privacy by design principles in all new features and systems
